solution_line_template: The fourth week had twice the number of employees as the third week, so {employees_fourth_week}/{twice_factor} = <<{employees_fourth_week}/{twice_factor}={employees_third_week}>>{employees_third_week} employees on the third week.

In the third week, they hired {fewer_than_second_week} fewer employees than on the second week, that is {employees_third_week}-{fewer_than_second_week} = <<{employees_third_week}-{fewer_than_second_week}={employees_second_week}>>{employees_second_week} employees hired on the second week.

The first week had {more_than_second_week} more hirings than the second week, that is {employees_second_week}+{more_than_second_week} = <<{employees_second_week}+{more_than_second_week}={employees_first_week}>>{employees_first_week} employees.

The total number of employees hired is {employees_first_week}+{employees_second_week}+{employees_third_week}+{employees_fourth_week} = <<{employees_first_week}+{employees_second_week}+{employees_third_week}+{employees_fourth_week}={total_employees}>>{total_employees}.
The average number of employees hired per week is {total_employees}/{number_of_weeks} = <<{total_employees}/{number_of_weeks}={average_employees_per_week}>>{average_employees_per_week} employees.
